references: We conduct experiments on four benchmark datasets which are available in torchvision
, following the existing FL with non-IID data work

.
In detail, G-FL uses the original

published in the torchvision to
evaluate methods that improve the global model.
In P-FL, we compare the average local performance of methods that enhance the local models, by
simulating non-IID local data distribution with the

published in torchvision.
For all datasets, we construct the non-IID data distributions via Dirichlet sampling

.
That is, we sample a proportion of

denotes the data distributions is more heterogeneous.
We construct

by randomly
sampling 75% of local data, and
with three categories of SOTA approaches by optimization goals, i.e., (1) optimizing global model:
, and (3) optimizing both global and local models:
is the first vanilla federated learning framework to collaborate among server and clients.
takes a proximal term to regularize the change from global model to the local model.
considers the variance of the global model and local model when updating local gradients.
applies a dynamic regularizer to pull the local model close to the global model, while pushing the local model away from the previous local model.
introduces contrastive learning to federated learning.
is an algorithm that takes personalized learning as a multi-task learning objective.
captures personalization aspects in FL by decoupling neural network model and avoiding aggregating personalization layers.
uses Moreau envelopes as clients’ regularized loss functions to decouple personalized model optimization from global model learning.

develops a scalable solver for
providing personalization while retaining similar efficiency.
adaptively learns to personalize the client models.
explicitly decouples a model’s dual duties with two prediction tasks.
only updates the representation body of the model during federated training, and the head is fine-tuned for personalization.

is a hyperspherical federated learning framework to
address FL with non-IID data.
We evaluate the global model of the first and third categories of work on G-FL, and the averaged performance of local models in the second and third categories of work on P-FL.
We set the number of clients
, and seek global updating direction in
as the feature extractor for EMNIST and FMNIST, while ResNet

for Cifar10 and Cifar100.
For all of the datasets, we set batch size as 128, and embedding dimension similar to the output of the representation model, i.e., 64 for ConvNet and 512 for ResNet.
For
as the optimizer, set the learning rate

,
and the effect of contrastive discrimination

.
We conduct training for all methods with 5 local epochs per round until converge.
We evaluate both G-FL and P-FL by top-1 accuracy.
We set the non-IID degree
, respectively, to test model on different degrees of heterogeneity.
